ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Translation from french to english while learning to utilize online resources and interpret things in the right context!

I learned to think critically about what role a translator plays and developed my skills in analyzing a french text, adapting idiomatic expressions, moving between french and English grammar, and refining word choice to best convey the author's meaning.

Basics of literary translation: differences between French and English, the difficulty and research required to select the right words, importance of language register and writing style, discussions about staying true to the author vs freedom in translation
How to immerse myself in the mind of the author.

I learned a lot about specific techniques employed and details to be aware of in translation, such as sentence structure, idiomatic expressions, and punctuation. I also gained knowledge on different resources to use in translation, and developed skills in finding a balance between literal and liberal translation styles. Additionally, this course really changed the way I read French and how I view translated pieces in general now, since I now understand all the thought that goes into a good translation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved this course! Very well structured (one translation per week) and facilitative to student learning.

The format of this course, with a first draft of one translation and the final draft another due almost each week, was very effective. The workload was not at all overwhelming and the opportunity to work with peers as well as Prof. Waters was quite useful.

I enjoyed the wide variety of texts, each with their own difficulties and interesting takeaways. I'm not sure there were many weaknesses since this class was exactly what it sounds like (ie translation), but sometimes the workshop format where you translate the text for homework and then pair up to discuss phrases that were challenging became a bit repetitive after a few weeks.

The strengths of this course were Professor Waters' passion for translation and the interesting assortment of assignments we were given. I thought the pieces Professor Waters chose for us to work on were all very different in style and all posed different challenges, so each assignment was exciting. I also really enjoyed the workshop style of the course since I've never been able to work so closely with my peers before and have so much of a course centered on hands-on learning. I don't think this course had any weaknesses, and I hope the style of this course is maintained for the future.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course only to other students who are very confident in their French proficiency and who enjoy somewhat tedious work of literary analysis, dictionary scouring, and intensive editing. You really improve a lot over the semester and the work is worthwhile, but it can feel monotonous at times.

Yes! But this was Prof Water's last semester teaching it and I imagine this course is very professor-dependent. The workload is very light (you translate around 500 words before class every week, one midterm in-class translation, one 2000 word final project) and then talk about the week's translation (as a group and in pairs). I understand that the best way to learn how to translate is to translate and that there may not be much to "teach," so while I did gain a lot of experience I'm not sure I can articulate exactly what I've learned after this semester. My French didn't really improve, but that also isn't the goal of the class. So I would recommend taking it as a fun, low-stress class and if you think you'd enjoy translating.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any other student studying French! Although Professor Waters is retiring, she was such a passionate and inspiring professor. Also, this course was genuinely just a lot of fun. Having a course focus on the subtleties and nuances of language was genuinely such a dream for me, and this course really changed the way I read French and understand translation between any languages. This course also introduced me to so many different styles of literature and different authors, which I think any French student would greatly benefit from.
